locations.name: Triveni Ghat
locations.description: One of the most sacred ghats in Rishikesh, famous for its evening Ganga Aarti. A peaceful spot where three holy rivers are believed to meet. Perfect for experiencing the spiritual essence of Rishikesh.

locations.name: Janki Setu
locations.description: A beautiful pedestrian suspension bridge offering stunning views of the Ganges and surrounding hills. Less crowded than Laxman Jhula, it's perfect for peaceful walks and photography during sunset.

locations.name: Neer Garh Waterfall
locations.description: A stunning two-tier waterfall located about 5km from Rishikesh. A short trek through the forest leads you to this refreshing natural pool, perfect for a quick dip.

locations.name: Beatles Ashram
locations.description: The abandoned ashram where The Beatles stayed in 1968. Now covered in colorful graffiti art, it offers a unique blend of spiritual history and street art in a serene forest setting.

locations.name: Patna Waterfall
locations.description: A hidden gem away from the tourist crowds. This beautiful waterfall requires a scenic trek through villages and forests, offering an authentic local experience.

locations.name: Kunjapuri Temple
locations.description: Perched at 1676m altitude, this temple offers breathtaking panoramic views of the Himalayas. Famous for stunning sunrise views over snow-capped peaks.

locations.name: Kasmoli
locations.description: Kasmoli is a serene village and emerging eco-tourism destination located in the Narendra Nagar Tehsil of Tehri Garhwal district, Uttarakhand, India. It is situated approximately 30–45 km from Rishikesh, making it a popular hidden escape for travelers seeking mountain solitude and Himalayan views.

locations.name: Little Buddha Cafe
locations.description: A popular, laid-back, treehouse-style cafe on the Laxman Jhula road, known among backpackers for its multi-cuisine menu (including vegan options) and outstanding views of the river and mountains from its balconies.

locations.name: Kyarki Sunset Point
locations.description: A breathtaking vantage point situated on the hill top near the Neer Garh Waterfall road. It is famous for offering mesmerizing golden sunset views over the mountains and the shimmering Ganges river below, making it a favorite spot for photographers and nature lovers.

locations.name: Balkuwari Mata Mandir
locations.description: Balkumari Temple is a sacred hilltop shrine dedicated to Goddess Parvati in her child form (Bal). Located approximately 25–44 km from Rishikesh in the Pauri Garhwal district, it is one of the region's 'Siddh Peeths'. The temple is renowned for its spiritual tranquility and the approximately 300–400 stone steps visitors must climb to reach the summit, which offers panoramic views of the Hanwal River valley and surrounding Himalayan ranges.

locations.name: Sai Ghat Laxman Jhula
locations.description: Considered one of the cleanest and most serene ghats in Rishikesh, Sai Ghat is located near the iconic Laxman Jhula. It is less crowded than other major ghats, making it an ideal spot for yoga, meditation, and quiet reflection. The ghat features beautiful idols of Lord Shiva, Vishnu, and Mother Ganga, and hosts a peaceful evening Ganga Aarti performed by students from the nearby Sathya Sai school.

locations.name: OM Freedom Cafe
locations.description: A well-known backpacker haven situated on the banks of the Ganges near Laxman Jhula. Known for its relaxed bamboo-themed interior and soulful music, the cafe offers a multi-cuisine menu including Israeli, Italian, and vegan options. It is highly popular for its unobstructed views of the river and the mountains, especially during sunset.

locations.name: Parmarth Niketan Aarti Point
locations.description: Located at the Parmarth Niketan Ashram in Swargashram, this is one of the most famous sites for the evening Ganga Aarti. The ceremony is led by Vedic priests and ashram residents (rishikumars) and features a massive statue of Lord Shiva in a meditative pose. The ritual involves soul-stirring bhajans, prayers, and the lighting of lamps on the banks of the holy Ganges.
